name: Cataract Creek (Silverton)
description:
Introduction

There are two options to do the approach for this canyon.

(1) For one of the most breathtaking views anywhere, do the long route that takes you up to 12,200 feet in elevation and you drop in as the headwaters are forming in a massive horseshoe shaped valley reminiscent of the opening scene in Jurassic Park. At this point, when Alden, who had just come back from Hawaii and has done hundreds of canyons in the big western canyoning states, said this may be the most beautiful canyon he's ever seen, it made me realize how spoiled we are in the San Juan Mountains.

3 C III
7-9 hrs
Car Shuttle: 2.75 miles (4WD HC)
Approach: approx. 4.75 miles +1900' -1820'

(2) If you are only interested in the short, technical section, then you can park on County Road 7 right where Cataract Creek pours into South Fork Mineral Creek and follow the ice-climbers trail to the 10,000 foot level and from there work your way up the hillside for 600 feet of elevation gain to the top rappel. This approach would be a 3CII canyon, possible to complete in 2-3 hours.

3 C II
2-3 hrs
No shuttle, the road is well graded (2WD)
Approach: 0.45 miles +600'

For having only 4 rappels it's hard to rate any canyon very high. The 3rd rappel, a narrow slot with the full force of the water pouring on you, I felt was one of the best rappels I have ever done, out of thousands of rappels.

The "R" rating is due to the V slot with overhang on the 3rd rappel. Similar to Shaver Cut, it could be potentially fatal if someone were to get a foot caught in the V. There was no way to inspect inside the V as all of the water is flowing down in a powerful laminar flow at this point.

Approach

From Ouray Hot Springs Park, drive south on Highway 550 for 21.5 miles. There is a sign for South Mineral Campground on the right. Make a right and you will be on County Road 7. Drive 4.4 miles to South Mineral Campground and reset your odometer. After South Mineral Campground, high-clearance is required. Drive an additional 1.9 miles on CR7 and there is a small turn-out on the left, room for one car. Park here.

If you get to a Y in the road with a branch leading off to the right and to a mine, you have gone too far. Turn around here and backtrack for about 2/10 mile.

There is a very faint use-trail heading down to the creek. You can see a muddy trail about 2 feet wide leading up the other side. This is the Hardrock 100 Trail. It is barely visible unless you happen to come soon after the race itself. Take this trail. After crossing South Fork you will gain elevation rapidly for about one mile. Thereafter, the trail levels out a bit. Hike another mile or so. You will dip down slightly in elevation before heading up and crossing a small stream. A few hundred feet further along and you can hear Porcupine Creek to your left. Continue another couple miles up the Hardrock 100 Trail and all the way up to the pass. You will be above treeline.

Elevation 12,282 feet at the pass between Porcupine Creek Basin and Cataract Creek Basin. Alpine Tundra environment. Continue east on the trail to a gulley heading north, down into the massive valley below. This gulley at the head and southernmost point of the rim, is your drop-in to the valley level. Down-climb to the valley floor going through a boulder strewn hillside. Follow the creek north and across the valley.

From the drop-in at 12,000 feet to the top of the technical section at 10,400 feet is a long hike over a couple miles and dropping 1,600 feet. As you get lower, the bushes get thicker and you are forced to stay in the watercourse more. There are many game trails making it easy to get down.

Descent

R1: 75' Rock Pinch, Canyon Left, very slippery, covered in moss
R1: 90' Higher water, using a tree slightly uphill Canyon Left

R2: 80' Tree, Canyon Left
R2: 25' Higher water, skirt the falls on Canyon Right from a tree

R3: 80' Rock Pinch, Canyon Left, two parallel V slots, overhang in narrow slot could result in foot entrapment and drowning

R4: 100' 2 stage rappel from a tree on Canyon Left.
* Option 1 is to go in the watercourse and drop into a slot being careful to navigate around a massive log - if you go behind the log you and/or the rope could get stuck; if you go over the log it is very slippery and dangerous.
* Option 2 is to stay canyon left of the watercourse and rappel down the dry rock wall

Exit

At the bottom of the 4th and final rappel, simply hike down the creek about 200 feet in elevation loss to get to the South Fork of Mineral Creek. Cross the creek and hike up the bank to the dirt road where your exit vehicle is parked.

Red tape

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

First canyoneering descent 8/20/2015 Logan DeGrand and Alden Anderson

2022-06-25 Ira Lewis and Ryan Humphries approached from the bottom. Photos and kml map added to this beta entry, with minor updates to original writeup by Logan. June water level was too high for the narrow slots of R3 and R4.

Background
